ÔªøWelcome to this episode of MATEHUNTERS
the one hole aella couldnt fill was her heart

Hi I‚Äôm looking for a boy i‚Äôd like to touch. Hopefully if you know a boy i would like to touch with this will help you identify him.
Things I want that most boys don‚Äôt have, roughly in order of how many boys they filter out and by how important/dealbreakery they are
*open to kids maybe??? and probably doesn‚Äôt already have kids/strong life commitments
*financially stable, bonus points for having more money than me
*independent, not looking to spend all their time joined at hip
*l i b e r t a r i a n  v i b e s
*social power roughly within an order of magnitude of mine, tho doesn‚Äôt need to be same sphere
*is open to risk, brave, caution is calculated, doesn‚Äôt let fear of bad outcomes affect taking life by the balls
*sexually sinister
*real good at [jazzhands] emotional maturity: stuff like detecting and naming emotions, having boundaries and a body, communication, ‚Äútalking from the stomach‚Äù, circling skills, mind meldy moves, speaking-from-poetry-instead-of-accuracy
*similar IQ range, which is higher than average but probably not as high as we‚Äôd hope
*not boring? I am deeply, profoundly bored by most humans. Everyone is deeply ok as they are I just prefer to spend my time doing puzzles, which are more interesting than most humans. 
*accepting of self and others, at peace
*good at (or at least compatible with/tolerant of) rationality n stuff, cold culture, happy to exchange money for social things, not easily horrified
how i‚Äôm poly
(full-ass post here)
Polyamory is very much mandatory for me, unless you‚Äôre a billionaire, because i am down to accept money in exchange for social things. For me, ‚Äúpoly‚Äù just means ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt place rules on the intimacy my partner has with others.‚Äù In practice, I tend to behave mostly romantically monogamously (prob due to lack of sufficient options i‚Äôm interested in), and I have a whole lot of casual sex and am happy to help my partners have casual sex too. I historically have been very helpful for connecting my partners with other women interested in them!

Im happy to commit time/effort to joint stuff like potential kids or house or ‚Äòrelationship development time‚Äô, even if it interrupts potential future relationships with other partners.
About Me?
The list of aella-facts is maybe less necessary cause i exhibitionist my personality loudly online into every crevice, but if you want an external list of nice things, my now-casual partner Nate Soares has a document originally entitled ‚ÄúMy ex is a shit eating whore‚Äù which is literally true but google thought he was trying to be mean so it‚Äôs now reuploaded here, where he tells people why i am good to date.


And for things about me that are maybe more nonobvious potential dealbreakers for people with specific preferences 

*80% cold culture
*however, can embarrassingly lose all skills when emotionally activated
*messy, horribly, tragically messy, but fortunately i am happy to exchange money for social things
*errs on the side of avoidant
*constantly dealing with stalkers you will have to protect me from
*i do not like directly initiating sex almost ever (tho doesnt mean you cant have as much sex as you want)
*despite playboy once describing me as having the ‚Äòbody of a thoroughbred stallion‚Äô, in practice i am gremlinesque, have computerneck, shower infrequently, and i sweat way more than normal and have very erratic poops
*not even the most basic cooking skills
*i like being on the computer a whole lot and dont like doing much outside stuff
*not routine oriented (tho i would like to be)
*do not like threesomes
*don‚Äôt have the ‚Äògirl magic‚Äô thing that some girls have where they emanate a soft glow of feminine nurturing care
*I‚Äôm not nurturing in general. I‚Äôm absentminded and am bad at tracking needs when those needs deviate significantly from my own. I still don‚Äôt remember my partners birthdays.


Also generic stats: born 1992, height 5‚Äô8, live in east bay

Me
Enthusiastic, driven to understand the fundamentals/first principles behind stuff, outgoing introvert, playful (but still British), introspective and self-aware, caring.

World views:
I‚Äôm a very open-minded classical liberal / Old Whig. I think people should have freedom, but I believe in morality (i.e. that some things are a bad idea). I value tradition as a good starting point, but I believe strongly in the advance of human progress.
Things I‚Äôm good at:
Joyful, driven optimism. Explaining complicated/technical things in simple/understandable ways. Writing. Recognising the difference between substance and form, and the difference between meta and on-topic. Maintaining a childlike spirit. Irrepressible curiosity. Seeing things from another‚Äôs point of view. Connecting people, creating/running communities. Using search engines to find the answers to stuff I don‚Äôt know. Ten-finger typing (~100 WPM). Listening to audio at x3 speed. Learning how to learn. Art theory.
Influences:
Karl Popper, David Deutsch, Richard Feynman, William Godwin, Thomas Szasz, Ayn Rand, Lewis Carroll, David Chapman.
If you‚Äôre into Popper/Deutsch, stop reading here and
just message me already
. ü•∞

Joe Hudson
(emotions, connection),

(productivity),
David Perell
(taking ideas seriously),
Michael Ashcroft
and
Peter Nobes
(Alexander Technique), and
Frank Anderson
(Internal Family Systems).
Relationship style
I‚Äôm looking to date towards a somewhat traditional, long-term relationship, ultimately leading to marriage & children. I‚Äôm a devoted partner, and I like pursuing my own interests and projects (if that‚Äôs with my partner that‚Äôs even better, but I‚Äôm happy having alone time too).
I want a masculine partner to complement my feminine wiles, but I‚Äôd like us able to explore any way of relating! Relationships can have
more
vibrancy and creativity when monogamous (and certainly more depth) than what‚Äôs possible otherwise. I dig this line from Peterson,
‚ÄúI‚Äôve slept with hundreds of women, and they were all my wife‚Äù
: an individual is so varied that you can have an infinite number of experiences with one person.
I‚Äôm a big romantic. ‚ù§Ô∏è¬† (And recovering edgelord.)
You
My ideal partner is someone
deeply curious
about the world so we can explore it together,
open-minded
so we can talk about anything,
socially skilled
so we can go anywhere and interact with anyone,
intellectually sharp
so we can challenge each other,
empathetic
so the relationship is deeply caring and understanding without needing words for everything, and
shares values
with me so we can be a well-functioning team. A bit of Feynmanian mischievousness doesn‚Äôt hurt either. üòÅ
Looking for someone in his 30s (or 29-43).
I‚Äôd like to connect over shared interests! Ideally one or more of my main interests:
‚ú¨
Philosophy
Epistemology, morality, consciousness, political & aesthetic philosophy
‚ú¨
Art
Classical painting, concept art, manga, comics, caricature, editorial cartoons
‚ú¨
Psychology
How the mind works, therapy, mental health, personal development & productivity
I have no height preferences, but if you work out that‚Äôs a big plus.
Family
I was home-educated and raised under
Taking Children Seriously
‚Äì a philosophy that aims to respect and help children by their own lights.
My life plan is to work on that philosophy, make it practical and accessible, and develop the movement. Figuring out how to create happy families and not break the spirits of children (and still have them function in the world) is, IMO, one of the most important things we can do upstream to facilitate human flourishing.
I‚Äôd like to find a partner willing to raise children with compassion, care and a profound respect for their autonomy.

Name: Nicole Kelner
ProfileText:
ÔªøHi potentially future boyfriend!


My name is Nicole! If you have somehow stumbled upon this google doc through the interwebs, I‚Äôm happy you‚Äôre here. I‚Äôm gonna go full listicle on you for this but I promise I can hold non-bulleted conversations üòÖ
  



My ~vibe~
* I smile and laugh a lot! I love doing silly things and going down rabbit hole conversations with strangers or friends 
   * Ex: I go to adult summer camps and my dream life would basically be having summer camp all year üòÖ
* I‚Äôm crafty! I can sew, knit, draw, paint, doodle, you name it. My love language is being able to sew buttons back on your shirt for you üòò 
   * Ex: I‚Äôm a full time artist and I make watercolor art about climate change. 
* In the words of the wise Nick Miller, ‚ÄúI just want to live a weird and wonderful life together.‚Äù 
   * Ex: I once hosted a peanut butter tasting to determine what brand is the best. Email me to find out üòâ 


Some things I value 
* Curiosity and creativity- I want a partner who follows their curiosity and likes to make things. That could be art, programming, music, whatever ‚Äúmaking‚Äù means to you.
* Silliness- I want someone to laugh with. 
* Nerdiness- Whatever you love, I love to hear about. I love a right brain/left brain combo.
* Empathy and kindness- Looking for someone who is kind to the people in their life and feels warm and fuzzy to be around. 
* Community minded- I love gathering friends and being a part of intentional communities. Looking for someone who wants to create shared experiences with people we love. 
* Exploring- I‚Äôve traveled a lot in the past and love the mindset of adventure. Right now I‚Äôm more interested in domestic travel and finding ways to explore my own city. I love weird art events, comedy shows, and getting out of the city on weekends.
* Grounding energy- I‚Äôm very creative and can float off into my own ideas. Having a grounding presence in a partner would be a nice balance. 
* Healthy- I love cooking, meditating, and swimming. Physical and mental health is really important to me! 


In terms of my work life, I‚Äôve always cared a lot about what I do and want to work in fields that I think are making a positive impact in the world:
* I started my first business when I was in my college dorm room. It was a handbag brand and I taught myself how to sew. I got hooked on entrepreneurship when I was 18.
* I worked for a digital nomad company called Hacker Paradise my last semester of college and traveled through Southeast Asia and Europe
* After graduation, I moved to NY and co-founded a kids coding program. We sold that in 2019.  
* I pivoted to working in climate tech. For fun, I decided to paint a watercolor a day for 100 days and it went viral. I quit my job after 4 months of painting and now make art about climate change full time! 
* I make custom watercolor infographics for climate organizations like the Department of Energy, Harvard, Sunrun, and Project Drawdown. I published a coloring book about clean energy. I love what I do so much! 


You‚Äôre also probably wondering about the facts you normally get on a dating app:
   * I‚Äôm 31 and 5‚Äô6‚Äù and looking for a monogamous relationship with a man. 
   * I don‚Äôt know if I want kids. I may be open to adopting, fostering, or having my own if it feels right down the road with the right person.
   * I‚Äôm vegetarian and don‚Äôt drink or do drugs.
   * I‚Äôm Jewish but don‚Äôt actively practice.
   * I live in NYC but don‚Äôt plan to forever. I‚Äôd love to live by a beach or lake in the future.


Green flags
   * You make a clear plan with time/location and check in the same day to confirm
   * You love what you do for work or have a hobby you love 


Say hi!
If you want to say hi, just shoot me an email at nicolek13@gmail.com. Tell me a bit about yourself and send over a photo! I have a preference to meet folks who live in NYC but I‚Äôm open to other cities.

Name: Mark
ProfileText:
ÔªøOriginal posted on a personals subreddit in January 2022.
Contact: date.mark.1co4i@simplelogin.com 
‚Äî


I think it is courtesy here to apologize for lengthy posts. I can tell you that there's no tl;dr; I hope that scrolling down something would catch your eye, and if I'm lucky, having read a paragraph enticed you to read more. I have very roughly tried to progress from the general to the particular; we know that the devil is in the details but it is the context that imbues it with significance. Words can only do so much to give a sense of a person, and I can hardly imagine a more anonymous place than a personals subreddit. If I may quote from a writer reflecting on his time as a drafted Vietnam war soldier,


> I confess that a large number of Americans I met in the Army amazed me by their differentness. I had not known their like before, nor have I met them since. Nothing else could have made me realize how narrow the circle in which we move in peacetime is. Most of us hardly get an inkling of how ninety per cent of our fellows live or think. Naively we assume that they must be like us or not very different.


And what is true about the American draft might be yet truer to the vast internet? Or is the variance narrower in Berlin?


My intention here is to give you as much sense of my person without you yet having met me. To read this fully will take you longer than reading other here ads, but less than riding the bike or U-Bahn to meet me, a ride that can be spared if you find something off in here lines from the comfort of your home or phone. If both of us are lucky, perhaps, on the contrary, it would give rise to that ride at the end of which two people, who did not know they missed each other, find each other and share a pleasant evening. And if we are very lucky, perhaps share many days thereafter.






Introduction


I'm a Russia-born, Israel-raised, 33 y/o (since two days!) who came to Berlin in 2014 for a master's and stayed here for work. A bit of an over-thinker, I love musing about and discussing the little and big things: how expectations shape our perception, how perception shapes our understanding of ourselves and the world; how attitudes are formed and how a given culture arises. The human mind, animal behaviour, culture, language, our political and economic system & its history have fascinated me since many years.


For my bachelor's I studied math and physics. The reason I chose that major was admittedly rather hoity-toity: I can't say it was the subject I was most interested in, but it was among the subject I was interested in and the one that, I thought, would be the most difficult to learn without others to guide me, i.e., teachers. The institution was a so called "liberal arts college" in the US and I took ample advantage of the opportunity to take courses outside my major, as well as going so far as borrowing text-books in the library to read over the summer; textbooks about social and evolutionary psychology and behavioural biology.


I started my master's for the "wrong reasons". By the last year of my bachelor's I was set to be done with academics and "start real life" (as if the term bore significance); I had wanted to leave Israel and to move to Europe. Seeing that it was too complicated to do so otherwise I chose what appeared to be the easiest route in: to start studying there. Since high-school I had had a particular attraction towards Germany, I think because of my Volga-German paternal grandfather who died before I was born, and because my favourite aunt lives in the city, but not wanting to narrow my choices I cast my net broadly, and so I could say I was lucky to find an intriguing program ausgerechnet in Berlin.


An unexpected googling result, the program was in "computational neuroscience," a term I did not know and which I had still not understood after reading its Wikipedia entry, but which, I thought, matched my case: the "computational" part matched my educational background and the "neuroscience" part matched my interest in the relationship between mind & body and the biological underpinning of human behaviour.


The program was difficult for me, for reasons that were personal (having looked too much outside my major during my bachelor's, making me somewhat less prepared than others; being used to a different student-professor relationship) and circumstantially unfortunate (not having been prepared for how difficult and time consuming finding a WG in my budget was, which itself brought further hardships), but I finished in good time. This "good time" was a long while, longer than programmed, but on par with my peers. As a classmate and friend had said, that it was a 2-years program was a lie.


My studies were followed by a long and therefore difficult period of job searching, looking for a position as a data-scientist, elongated by my difficulties with German (which since then I speak much better, also in my job), uncertainties about fine points of my then legal status in the country, and mostly by having little connections in Berlin and by being a bad judge of my own skills and abilities, always leaning diffidence-wards. Nonetheless I felt lucky at the end when ‚Äì‚Äìbeing ready to sell myself to any evil corporation to optimize its commercials or recommendations‚Äì‚Äì I got a job at a "medical-tech" company which employs machine learning to improve diagnostics of health complications during pregnancies. While I was hired as a data scientist, in the last few months, our team being understaffed, I did nothing but implement changes to our app. At least in our company xmas dinner the head of tech voiced that I was over qualified for the work that I was doing and the boss encouraged him to get me out of that and put me on the data as soon as possible.


Commitment to writing


To this day whenever I see a great piece of art, whatever the form ‚Äì‚Äìliterature, film, paintings, music, video games, furniture‚Äì‚Äì, I'm attracted by the idea of creating something similar, rarely going beyond the act of sketching blue-prints for future projects. What has stuck, however, is the decision I made when I was about 15, that I shall be a writer. For a very long time I had not been much of a writer and was reluctant using that title. I wrote mostly short story beginnings and fragments; I was surprised to find years later that these were not so bad, but all the same they didn't amount to much. When I first came to the US I remember telling others that I would never be able to speak English from the heart, but by a year or so later it had changed, and English is still my language of choice. A creative writing professor on my final year was very supportive; I used to think that she was merely nice, that is, to everyone, but later I heard different experiences from other students. All the same, perhaps I received special treatment as the odd non-literature student. All the same, it was encouraging.


My passion is in writing fiction, but I discovered the power of my writing to captivate people (as I hereby try to captivate you) on mundane occasions: emails to a different literature professor, about how I had found it difficult to keep up with the reading, who praised them during class(!) (they were written in an 18th century English, appropriately to the course); an excuse email to a tutor in my master's, for having failed to submit my homework, who wrote me back that I had made her day; personal and philosophizing ‚Äì‚Äìand often admittedly too long‚Äì‚Äì emails to friends, one of which had asked to forward an email to two friends of hers because she thought "it would help them."


All the while I was also writing the occasional not very good short story, sending it to one journal I had set my mind on, which has never accepted my submissions.


I had a minor breakthrough a few years ago, when I answered an ad recruiting team members to work on a so called indie video game. "Writers" were not sought but I found the ad intriguing and contacted the guy anyway, expressing my interest. We had some back and forth, he presented me his idea on a call and I wrote him back my opinion of the project. I expected our connection to end then and there: I was very critical of many aspects of his work, and us being strangers, I thought he would want to not have anything to do with me anymore. I was critical not because I wanted to bring him down or insult him, but precisely because I liked the guy and his attitude and so cared enough to take the time, risk the "being not nice" in order to share my point of view. He wrote me back to say that he found my comments helpful, and from then on we collaborated. When I told him that I no longer had time for his project (this was during my job-searching period; my time went to answering postings and on making myself qualified for the positions I was seeking), he offered to pay me to write for his game  ‚Äì‚Äì an offer I accepted. So I may say that I have been paid for my writing, I almost forgot about it. The breakthrough came from the fact that his approach to story-telling/ sharing ideas, let's say, was very akin to mine, and seeing it from the outside I became aware of its shortcomings, storytelling-wise.


Just over a year ago I had the last of piecemeal revelations which brought about a major leap. After involving a good friend of mine in my endeavour, I began to write regularly, daily, with clear aims before me. My new expedient attitude had set me to write short stories but my expansive nature (a hint of which you might be picking up) proved to me that I am more of a (potential) novelist. I'm currently working on a novel and I am glad to announce that it has been progressing very well.






I & honesty


For a great part of my life I held honesty (being true) and openness (being transparent) to be prime virtues. These served me well:


when I was drafted to the IDF, the Israeli Defense Force, I was put into artillery, a combat unit. While I enjoyed the training (truly a "guilty pleasure"), when it came to being part of maintaining the occupation, I couldn't do it. I asked my direct commander for a conversation and laid it out to him: I didn't believe in this and that, refused to continue cooperating, and explicitly expressed my willingness to go to military prison if my words amounted to insubordination. I was surprised to find that the commander ‚Äì‚Äìwhose very different political leaning/ worldview was known (I was amused when he told me that his girlfriend was "just like that, too")‚Äì‚Äì responded very graciously. The rest of the story is rather involved to lay down here completely, but the bottom line was that honesty received its points. I approached my problem with words and it was rewarded.


Then there was the matter already written here, about coming to my teachers and making explicit my shortcomings as a student, which were always met with support. I also wouldn't forget how in high-school a good friend of mine came to the math teacher with his graded exam and showed her how one of his solutions, despite a mistake he had made, was marked as correct. She answered that he was right that he was wrong, but let him keep the grade. Together with other friends I remonstrated, though only in jest, we respected his action.


Generally with my friends I always found that opening up yielded positive results. I wouldn't forget how towards the end of my second year of college my roommate wrote me a long Facebook message where he expressed a resentment he had towards me, to which thitherto I was unaware, mentioning that "[I] remembered how you told me once that it's better to talk about issues rather then holding on to it, so I thought it would be good for us to talk about it." He vented his grudges, I apologized, we discussed it and sorted it out.






But I have also experienced the limits of honesty. My t√™te-√†-t√™tes with commanders buoyed up the ranks up to the battalion commander who did not, like the others, simply hear me out, but "argued" with me. After that conversation I deliberated with myself about whether in some circumstances "lying was ok." Recognizing the shortness of the power of my words, I resorted to action ‚Äì‚Äì which despite the military settings and my internal sense of drama, did not involve helicopters, shooting or explosions.


When in college I told my Nabokov course professor that I couldn't, that is, wouldn't, write the final paper for the course because I had a greater calling (my then novel in writing) and she gave me the grade that I deserved, adjusted by sympathies.


During my long job-searching period my honest but implicit importing of my lack of ability to assess the comparison between my relevant skillfulness with that of the imagined potential competition's might have been taken as an expression of a lack of aptness in the skills themselves, or so one could imagine. And so I did imagine, along with hundreds other stories of why it was that I wasn't getting a job (none of which, though you probably didn't think so, had to do with immigrants).






In the army I was trying to "follow the rules", to follow my agreeable nature <3, while not following them. I now wonder that there was an effect that was as paradoxical as that in the liar's paradox. I observed once a soldier being immediately punished upon his refusal to pick up a shell during drilling (I now wonder if I had been anything to inspire; it was after my disobedient "coming out" and I was passing by him), a response very different to the one I had received. My refusal bore the structure of "I thereby break the rule," and had the effect of excusing myself from all that I did not want to do while being dealt with as if I was operating within the rules. For a long period I was let to merely "hang around", only being assigned only cleaning and watch duties.


With my Nabokov course professor I was being honest when I told her that I wanted to dedicate the time to my fiction project, but I was in fact also proving myself a point, namely, that I was free from the expectations of institutions, or, more exactly, that I came to school to learn and not to be accredited, and since I was not going to continue on the academic path (which turned to be false) my final grades were not important and putting the effort to prove a professor that I deserved her good opinion and thereby sacrificing my art(!!) was plain silly. And perhaps I wanted her to think of me as a bud of something as great as Nabokov. And also I was trying to repeat a trick that did work for me in Freshman year (A; but there was more heart in it) than in that senior year (C; if I recall correctly).






What's the point of the above? It is not the case that honesty per se has rendered me a disservice, but rather that being honest is not always very trivial. For one thing, words do not merely carry the information they directly encode, but establish a certain relationship between the speaker and recipient. As you are reading it, presumably, you are not building a picture of myself based just on the content of my words, but also on my choice of things to include, their order, what I exclude. You might wonder, to put it simply, why I am telling you certain things.


I think this is the reason why I enjoy having "theoretical discussions" with people with Asperger's or who are close to "that end of the spectrum"; from my experience they don't take their opinions so personally so when I disagree with them they don't take it to mean that "I dislike them" or that "we do not get along".






The phenomenon which seems to me to best capture the dynamic between words and the relationship they engender between the people using them is that of flirting. And I think what is true with flirting, in a long but circumscribed moment between two persons, is true for all interpersonal communications and their Wittgensteinian language games.


What do the flirters do? There's a play that is not merely about reflecting reality as one sees it but about negotiating, implicitly, the creation of a new reality: the potential transformation of a "one and a one" into "a two" into a different kind of "one"; the flirters bring in their expectations of the nature of this new unit, they bring in their expectations of the expectations of the other person, they discuss the unit, they gauge the other's willingness and adequateness and entice the other into the unit by proving that they are fit for their own part. There's always the question: is the other merely a nice person, that is, nice to everybody, or specifically nice to me? Is this person habitually touchy or are they hitting on me? Does the other person tell me about their recent break up because they have an urge to share the fresh experience? Because they want advice? Because they want to communicate to me their availability?


A memory of non-flirting comes to my mind. I was at a Berlin lake's beach. A small group of cheerful gals was sitting on the next spot. A guy, who evidently had had some interaction with them earlier, approached and spoke to one of them. He said that he was new in the city, that he didn't know much people, and asked if she would be his friend, wanted to exchange numbers. I had a perfect view of this interaction, and I suspected that the naive and simple approach was a poorly disguised trick, that he was trying to pick her up, and the gal, who was not born yesterday, must have suspected likewise. As you might imagine, the gal declined his kind offer and after a bit of insistence the guy left. What works in kindergarten (and in A Beautiful Mind) often doesn't work in the adult world.


I admit that, unfortunately, I'm not good at flirting, but I recognize that while words can try to describe that which happens between one person and another, they cannot define it, cannot conjure it out of nothingness by themselves. It seems to me that people don't even always know what they themselves want, and if they do, they don't know what they might desire in the future, after they discover something or their circumstances change. Words are a combination of bearing witness to the present, reporting on the past and making a prediction, or a promise, onto the future, and therein their ambiguity.


How do we remain honest, report things about ourselves as they are, when we are aware that we are constantly changing? When we know that we continue to disappoint our own selves? When we know, perhaps, that our self disappointment is a sign that we had set ourselves high-bars that we worked hard to strive towards, without which we would have remained lying on the bottom? How do we promise "eternal love" when we have no regard for any church's allotted sanctity and we witness divorces as a normal occurrence around us, and know that we, too, are only human?  






As you understand, this is not a call for dishonesty, lack of commitment or the abandoning of communication of needs and expectations. It is not the case that I think that words are meaningless or that "there's no truth" (I'm already answering protractors, but I trust that you understand me). No. This is a petition to act out a relationship between us


where language is used to improve each other's and our surrounding's lives and conditions ‚Äì‚Äì I don't mean that we will fix the world with words, but that we won't violently force words upon it, or argue about words as if they were the matter themselves;


where we employ language as a tool to understand each other and not to bind each other, committed to the idea that each one of us has one's needs, desires, energies and fancies that need to be humoured and supported in our effort of maintaining our togetherness.


Since it has not been yet stated quite so unequivocally: I am looking for a single woman to form a dyad with, to give meaning to each other with, to figure out the world with, and when the world is ready for it, raise some children with. There. This last part goes somewhat against what I mentioned when on the topic of flirting, but as there are people who are certain they do not want to have children it made sense to mention it. But that would anyhow be in the far future, and we do not need to discuss it yet. We take it all in baby-steps. We are considerate.






I & Shyness


This has been the big drama of my adolescence. When I was 12 I realized that I was shy. It's seems funny to me that such things have to be learned, but there's no escape from the fact that when we are born we do not "know ourselves," in the most trivial sense, and need time to be discovered to our own selves. Need "time" meaning the occasion for the discovery; in my case it was watching the series Neon Genesis Evangelion with its timid protagonist Shinji. It incited an interest in psychology, which the then young internet (pre-google!) led me to believe equaled Freud's Id and Ego and the rest of it. I diagnosed myself with "social phobia", a recognition with which I turned with glee, as if I had solved a great mystery, to others: to classmates on MSN messenger, with whom I hadn't otherwise spoken in school, who listened; to my friends, one of which mocked my diagnosis and denied it. Be as it may, I found out soon enough, on a classmate's Bar Mitzvah party, that being aware of a problem is not quite 80% of having solved it, and that while Shinji supposedly overcame his issues on the last episode I had watched that same day, he did it alone ‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì without me.


I asked my parents to take me to the therapist, which they did. I remember drawing a boy, describing it, and being shy about drawing a girl. This sounds caricaturistic, but I remember being given the Rorschach test, and describing a scene of two alien kingdoms sealing an accord of peace with the touch of their leaders' long index-fingers ‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì a scene that upon searching it years later, though having found the implicated Card X, I couldn't again see. At a trough I was suggested antidepressants and I must have hinted willingness because next the psychiatrist and my parents appeared; I also remember that the offer was left to me to decide (by the staff? by my parents? unaware of it when young, I was almost amazed when I reflected on it as an adult at the degree of trust my parents had always put in me) and that I declined it. I don't remember how long I attended sessions; it was at least a few months and less than a year. I had gotten some insights out of it but eventually decided that I felt like it was not helping me much, and I was out. This, by the way, was the last time that I sought "professional help" for "mental health" related issues, though not the last time that I suffered of anything of that sort. That being said, while still occasionally having been afflicted with depression afterwards, I am happy to say that since my early twenties I have learned to cope with the little devils in my head and since two years they are positively gone (without, as Rilke has put it, the angels having fled with them).






Throughout my adolescence I invested a lot of thought into my problem of shyness, and what brought the eventual succour was a simple change of circumstances. For 9 years I had attended the same school, the same class of 40 kids, and the simple transition to a different school, when high-school came around, and its requirement to make new acquaintances, was of great help. I did not make it very easy for it to do so, however: in my high-school the classes were reshuffled every year, with the exception of two: one which was "special" in the euphemistic sense (but not too special; I think it was called the "sports class") and the other was the gifted class. I tell you right away that I had not undergone any tests to get into the latter. When I came to register for high-school ‚Äì‚ÄìI remember being alone with the secretary in her office‚Äì‚Äì I said that I wanted to be in gifted class. That was enough to get admission. It's one thing with young rosy cheeked children, I suppose a teenager's willingness alone, in that angsty age, is enough of a criterion.


If in high-school I put myself in one "extreme" of being again in the same class and its group of students all-throughout, the army (which is a whole story on its own) was on the other: already mid-training I had been moved from one unit to another, a pattern that continued until my discharge with a rough average of one month per unit, having to make new acquaintances on each transition. It was during this time, incidentally, that the seeds of my affection towards FKK had been sown; it made as much sense to go to the showers together as it did to go to dinner together. Why shower alone when you can shower and have a conversation at the same time? This idea comes to me now for the first time in my life: let's have two showers. Make it big, give it two showerheads, so we could shower together. Tongue in the cheek but serious nonetheless!


The army was the beginning of the end of my problem. I know that in college I still considered myself an introvert because a TED talk about introverts inspired me to follow the advice of "taking advantage of what introverts were good at" (I'm paraphrasing) and "express myself in writing rather than face to face" to tackle an uncertainty that I had in the wooing of my then crush. I copied (unnecessarily, though it felt more personal that way) in handwriting a long letter that I composed for her. That I ended up awake until four in the morning was because of the calligraphy I rendered on the front page, which I thought was not so bad for a first attempt. This, as you might imagine, did not work so well, and was hinged partially on the misguided sense that a romantic relationship could be agreed on when in fact it should be developed. And on my impatience, perhaps. If it was the first then I admit it was not the last of grand gestures made thus by me for such purposes.


Ten sonnets that I wrote to a stranger who had twitted "Pablo Neruda wrote a hundred sonnets to his wife while I can't get a guy to go to acro yoga with me idgi" won me a phone number + a reserved willingness to meet for coffee, but either my apologetic reply email or my stumblings on our short WhatsApp correspondence made her turn the other cheek.


Then was a long half love letter half Ode to Berlin written to an Ok-Cupid connection. We had corresponded extensively on the days preceding her visit to Berlin, had a skype and hung out a couple of times while she was here. I sent her the email while she was travelling in Hungary after Berlin. Well: she didn't want to have anything with me afterwards.


I have learned my lesson, alluded to on the previous section about words and honesty, and that Ode to Berlin was the last time I attempted anything of this sort. I am not unaware that this here post is of the same genre, me jumping around, feeling like a bird of paradise trying to captivate your attention and pique your interest. However, this time I do not pretend that I know who you are, nor what sort of relationship we might develop together.






Why have I written so much? Am I desperate? Crazy? Obsessed?


I am not desperate, but concerned. Indeed, my self sufficiently leads me to believe that if I do not do anything about it, I could easily go through life by myself. A good friend joked that I was preparing for the covid situation all of my life. Indeed, I am not unhappy alone but I am often sad that I do not share my life with more people. And my wish to make a family one day is dear to me.


Crazy? Maybe a little but not in disconcerting ways. I have, anyhow, encouraged others' notion of myself as being a little fou fou; people start to expect the unexpected, in little ways, which means that they do not quite judge me by their usual standards, which is liberating. Or this is how I have explained it to myself; perhaps they do judge me all the same within themselves but they have not complained and I am happy to beat my own drum.


Obsessive? Maybe. It took me a good decade and a half to cultivate a passion for writing, and it is there that my obsession perhaps lies; it is no less powerful for being self-made. As it may be, I enjoy writing, telling stories, sharing my ideas and, most of all: having conversations, for which writing could hopefully at least (but also: only so much) set a table. As Yoel Hoffmann wrote in "Curriculum Vitae":


> If I could [in a sort of pact that was deeper than that between an author and a reader] fall on the necks of people and tell them: come and let us sit and steep tea and drink and you will tell me your life and I will tell you my life, I would have tossed the manuscript in the paper bin and done it.


As I see it, I'm just trying to present myself and attract the like minded. I'm not trying to dance the tango alone. This post is not the final word but the excuse, the occasion, to discuss things. Any written word, anyhow, can remain valid only so long. This is just the beginning, as Melannie C sings.






By the end of college I was no longer sure how valid my former placement of myself on the introvert-extrovert scale was, important only as a function of my interest in the so called Big Five Model. I have been enthusiastic and talkative in companies I cared about since childhood, only it took a couple of decades for me to find myself comfortable with people I had just met. Consulting Wikipedia, I'd say I suppose I am indeed an introvert, only the social aspects don't quite apply.


Perhaps because of the long way it had taken me, this is something I am proud of to the point of bragging about it:


When I first came to college I held the childish bratty opinion that people who danced were shallow and stupid. A year and a half later I sought to "learn to dance": I asked a roommate and a friend about it; the one told me that he didn't actually know how to dance (I thought otherwise) and that he had always felt ashamed whenever he went to clubs where were good dancers; the other told me to make love to the music. With this information and with the simple yet very useful Wikihow instructions on the topic(!) (ask me about it; I bet it has changed since then. Now it probably includes the steps "stay hydrated" and "eat fresh fruit") I gradually came to the present point where dancing is one of my favourite things to do. Unfortunately these plague days have not offered much opportunity to dance with other people, though I do it from time to time alone in my room. And the braggy part: already then a friend told me that I was the best dancer in our college, which I thought was a mighty exaggeration but I took it anyway. Since then almost every time that I dance in public, at night (I guess people have to be at least a little tozy-mozy), a stranger(!) would approach me to compliment my dancing. Once a person came to me and handed me a flower "for the best dancer on the dancefloor." Among my circles enthusiastic dancers are not so common, so I welcome getting know people with this passion :) But as I said, most of the people I like are not keen dancers, so that's fine, too.






~






The first dialogues that I ever came up with, even though I didn't write them down, were a direct consequence of my shyness. On the afternoon that serves as the best example, I was working myself up to call to book tickets for games on a then forthcoming RPG conference. I couldn't, in my anxiety, just pick up the phone and call. Instead, I imagined the interaction, playing through the various possible sequences of the imminent exchange, depending on whether there were still seats on this or that game, all the while pacing my room back and forth. Possibly it had taken an hour until I did manage to make the call.


The conference was not very easy, nonetheless; I find amusing the notion of being shy/awkward within a gathering for playing pen and paper RPG, stereotypically perhaps the geekiest of activities. Having been an outlier age-wise in the conference (still in middle-school, not sure what year this was), did nothing to improve. Towards the end of one of the games attention was turned to me; this was an act of kindness by one Idit ‚Äì‚ÄìI knew her as a personality on the Israeli RPG forum‚Äì‚Äì who wanted to include the thitherto quiet player. I became flustered and I felt my cheeks growing warm.






~






Another aspect of my shyness that has to do with my writing, as well as with the attitude I have developed towards "honesty", was a fear ‚Äì‚Äìif that's the right word‚Äì‚Äì of lying. Equipped with an inaccurate theory of mind, it seemed to me that any potential lie was obvious in its deviation from the truth. It occurred to me recently that fiction writers are really professional lie-yarners. My shying away from "being caught lying" had made fiction writing difficult to me, but at the same time, I believe, it leads me to write better. I carefully scrutinize all I write and it helps making the text hold better together.  


Fiction writers make a certain implicit ceremony, like shamans summoning spirits to possess them, before they begin their narration (and when they don't, as was the case with "A Million Little Pieces", things do not remain quiet), and we do not take their words at face value. Nonetheless, it's precisely the extent to which their stories ring true that we enjoy them.






I & Sex


If hunger can be the excuse or opportunity to create something beautifully tasty, so can be the urges of the loins. While I esteem some of Buddhism's ideas regarding wanting & suffering, I think life is to be enjoyed. Perhaps am an epicurean, in the sense of valuing the cultivated pleasure, but maybe that's just hot air. I think life should be enjoyed ‚Äì‚Äì the generality of this sort of sentence's amounts to be meaningless without some context, but I don't know that I could articulate it. Godard films spring to my mind, perhaps due to my idea of the French idea of joi de vivre, though I can't say I recall Belmondo ever playing anybody who particularly enjoyed life.


I don't want to give you the wrong impression that my life is full of indulgent sensuality and excitement. I love hiking but I do not do it often, and if you find me in the jungle with a knife in my teeth, it is likely to be in imagination and not in body. I would have loved to be surrounded by harpists and marble, eating oysters inside a warm milk bath, but I choose my battles: on can have some but not all pleasures the world has to offer, and I'm mostly aiming at a different category. A year or two ago I did fix myself a hot bath and read in it. The effort, aggravated by the fact that the boiler's volume was smaller than the bathtub's, that the water cooled down rather quickly, that there was scarcely a dry place to put the book down on, made it not worth it. And still I repeated this once or even twice.


I think our fancies should be obliged!


I think what I value most is the pursuit of art and science, which I find to be close kin of each other rather than the polar opposites they often portrayed as. Let us invest our resources into meeting our needs, into sustaining ourselves, and the rest into creating the true and beautiful, whether taken by our senses or by our thoughts ‚Äì‚Äì or, as often is the case, by their combination. Sounds lofty, I suppose, but a good direction to go in. :)






My French friends might look askance at me saying it, but I take some care to eat tastily. And when I make food for others I try to make it beautiful. I would not forget how my father (who has never cooked) heated up in the microwave for my return from school a simple dish of rice and toppings that my mom had made, and presented it as "The seven samurai climbing up a snowy mountain".






I hold the above all the more so with regards to sex since in it, in a sense, we consume each other, and therefore take the relish personally. One could either gobble up potatoes to kill one's stomach rumbles, or take the most out of a meal by using it to express care, explore the senses, keep oneself healthy and in love with life. I call for sex to be used to relieve each other's stresses, to let us understand each other's and our own bodies better, learn our pains and pleasures. I would not have said it if I didn't get the idea that some view it differently, but in sex I had relished nothing more than the expressions of pleasure of my partner. My own little death, if you allow me, is almost a disappointment, like the end of a good movie that is bound to come but oh how we wish there was more.


And, yes, sex could be used to negotiate and to come in terms with each other: sex is but a special case, the case where it is most obvious that our requirements are asymmetrical. What is fair? 1:1 can be fair but so could 3:1. This depends on how we measure fairness, which could hark back to the old but ever present economical question of "what is value". Does it depend on the intensity of the need, of the satisfaction, of the effort to bring it? I say: let us be generous, to ourselves and each other, in sex and otherwise.


Posting this ad


I feel like it's not the place, but nonetheless I want to start with a technological lament. Perhaps you are familiar with it, perhaps not: OK-Cupid, a little more than five years ago, was a great tool. I met through it my last girlfriend, I've met one of my still best friends, and had numerous other nice interactions. I found its q&a based "match" calculations to be neat and helpful. Since then it has been sold and transformed into an awful Tinder-like slot machine. This has nothing to do with the present ad, but: I certainly think that the world needs to have such a platform recreated.


For what it's worth though I still have an account there and if you do too, we could look at the percentage. Perhaps we are the kind that trust that math.






While I was looking for a job my finances were so stringent that it made me often eschew even going out with friends, to say nothing of dating. I had a real sense of lying outside society by the void in my pockets.


Now that it is not a consideration, society is amidst a plague. My employment straddles its very beginning: I was offered my job before "Corona" meant anybody anything but a beer, and signed the contract with a mask and disinfected hands. Between these two points was a dramatic suspense. The confirmation of the project's budget by the Charit√© was delaying and I worried that money would be redirected to virus-related research, of which our project was not one, leaving my own travails ongoing.






Since a couple of months I've joined a few meetup book-clubs and already made a friend, and then came the great new surge of covid cases that pushed people back to online meetings. Well, you know the situation, I don't need to tell you about it.


My fancifully hopeful intention is to be able to make a connection, like magic, through these here words. I say "like magic" not just because the effect would be brought up by a spell, but because the effect itself is akin to the sudden appearance of something out of nothing, like a pigeon inside a hat. I'm thinking here of Hannah Arendt and her writing (which I hold very dear), and how she formulated the coming into the world of people as the emergence of the New. She was referring to birth, but it applies to new connections just the same ‚Äì‚Äì a person emerging into the world of another. With all respect to "Recommended to you" algorithms, is there any occurrence more transformative and opening than the meeting and the engagement with a like minded stranger? Yes, my hopes are lofty but all the same worthy of the effort. :)








Here is explicitly an ad to find a partner, but I would be happy to make new friends of any gender as well, so if you are not looking, taken or already interested in me only otherwise, I encourage you to write me too. It's all very far from it, but I have had fantasies of living in a Seinfeld-world where friendly faces barged through the door unbidden. College was a little like this, and though at each moment I did not welcome unwelcome barging-ins, I knew that it made life better. I'm in Berlin, as the title has it, and though I recognize that our contact would begin and incubate online, my hope is that sooner than later we would sit around a shared table.






I don't expect things to happen quickly. As mentioned before, this is just the beginning. Love, as I see it, is not about "finding the right one," but about finding someone with whom to earn each other's trust to cultivate together a shared life. I'm thinking here of Alain de Botton's idea of "Lovers needing to be each other's teachers". One doesn't find love but grows it. A paragraph from Williams' Stoner comes to mind, too:


> In his extreme youth Stoner had thought of love as an absolute state of being to which, if one were lucky, one might find access; in his maturity he had decided it was the heaven of a false religion, toward which one ought to gaze with an amused disbelief, a gently familiar contempt, and an embarrassed nostalgia. Now in his middle age he began to know that it was neither a state of grace nor an illusion; he saw it as a human act of becoming, a condition that was invented and modified moment by moment and day by day, by the will and the intelligence and the heart.






This is stepping somewhat ahead, but in case it might be on your mind: I don't feel strongly rooted in Berlin. I have ogled the north and I can imagine an eventuality of myself moving to settle elsewhere, but at the same time I don't currently have a reason to do so. Learning German did make me break sweat, but no matter. Loving languages I'd be glad for a good reason to learn a new one. I'll learn yours!






An appendix of books and movies


The rest ‚Äì‚Äìfrom here down‚Äì‚Äì is much less important, and is provided for the sake of further self-description (to the extent such things testify) and maybe an opportunity for discussion ‚Äì‚Äì some things I recently watched, read, listened to. I'll be glad to take your recommendations and opinions of recent things you stumbled upon :)






I listen quite a lot to youtube videos whose audio I scrape, mostly talks and lectures. Podcast I've been listening recently to are Andrew Huberman's *Huberman Lab* podcast (I'd describe it as "applied neuroscience"; he's very careful with the statements he makes and has a nice voice) and David Harvey's *Anti-Capitalist Chronicles*. I used to listen to quite a lot of Zizek in the past.






Recent films:


*The French Dispatch*. Because I love Wes Anderson, admire his attention to detail, I'm hesitant to say that I liked this film but was a little disappointed. I liked it less than any of his others. At the same time, he was experimental here in ways new to him and there's one thing that ‚Äì‚Äìto me significant‚Äì‚Äì distinguishes it from him previous work, so I tell myself that it's a turning point for him and he needs time to find his new vision. It's also possible that I'd like it better on a second viewing.


*My Octopus Teacher*. I didn't like the narration, nor the style of the film, but I found it interesting. More than it taught me something about octopuses, it taught me about humans.


*Never look away*/ *Werk ohne Autor* ‚Äì loved it.


Laundry list of other recent movies I watched and loved: *Dolor y Gloria* (Pain and Glory); *–ë—Ä–∞—Ç* 1 and 2; *Microhabitat*; *Gespenster* (Ghosts); *Kr√≥tki film o mi≈Ço≈õci*; *Wife of a Spy*; *Pirosmani*.


I no longer see "favourite" to be very useful a term in this context, but for whatever it's worth, for a long time I considered *Lost in Translation* to be my favourite film. I remember when I first saw a poster for it, though I first watched it much later, when it came out on DVD. The attention the poster evoked in me probably has to do with the title and my then Japanophilia ‚Äì‚Äì the title was translated in Hebrew to "Lost in Tokyo"; is this irony or art? Later "my favourite" became "Adaptation", which I find very close to my heart. Either way, I'm looking forward for Sophia Coppola's and for Charlie Kaufman's next films. As well as those of






Books: the last book I read was *Cloud Atlas*. It was recommended by my aforementioned encouraging writing teacher, years ago, and had long stood on my shelf unattended. For some reason I thought I wouldn't like it (that there was a film based on it probably had, I must admit, something to do with it) but I was quickly captivated once I started. I loved it. Also, recently:


Auster's *The New York Trilogy*, which I loved (and have too much to say about).


I read most of Franzen's *Crossroads* but abandoned it towards the end. I had enjoyed it enough that if it was not the first of three installments I would have finished it. It's greatest offense was being under-edited (look who's talking, you might say!) and so I didn't care to go on. I did love his *The Corrections*, however. Generally, I'm trying to cultivate the habit of abandoning books that I don't enjoy and whose only promise is a sense of completion by their end.


I loved Morrison's *Beloved*; Ishiguro's *Never Let me Go*; Plath's *The Bell Jar*.


Had ambiguous feelings towards Zalkow's *a brilliant novel in the works*.


Just started McEwan's *On Chesil Beach*, loving it so far; am at the midst of Mazzucato's *The Value of Everything*, finding it very informative.






Ever since my WG turned into a Zweck WG (planning to move out) where I'm the only one eating at the kitchen, on days I work from home, I watch series. Currently watching *Breaking Bad* and *BoJack Horseman*, loving the latter in particular. Loved *Rick and Morty* (but who doesn't?) until that season when it wasn't it anymore. I suspect *The Wire* will nonetheless forever stand at the top.






When I do programming I like to listen to fast paced loud music such as that of Ling Tosite Sigure, Lightning Bolt, Igorrr. When I want to fondle my ears I listen to Animal Collective, Do Make Say Think, Amon Tobin, Mr. Bungle. The advice given to Charlie in *Adaptation* is "wow them at the end", but when I finish personals ads I end on a melancholic note.

Name: Tyler Alterman

Name: Eli Tyre
ProfileText:
Eli Tyre
Dating Profile
I'm a straight man,
years old.
I live an intense, pseudo-ascetic, life, focused on altruistic work, self-improvement, and personal-spiritual integrity. (Additional detail on my unusual lifestyle can be found
here
.)
I'm looking to go on dates with new people, with the possibility of long or medium-term partnership. I'm open to both monogamous and polyamorous relationships.
(More photos
here
.)
What I Want
I‚Äôm attempting to live with an
open heart
, robust ethics, and scrupulous epistemic standards. Above everything else, I want relationships, romantic or otherwise, that support and nourish me in that.
I'm open to two pretty different flavors of relationship:
a low-time-commitment, high-intimacy, companionship, on the one hand,
and a high intensity, high commitment, long-term Partnership, on the other.
Medium term - Once-or-twice-a-week companionship
Currently, I‚Äôm mainly looking for more companionship in my life.
I would like to have someone to spend time with about once or twice a week: talking, circling, co-working or strength training, cuddling, having sex, being curious together, all with a practiced expectation of being fully honest with each other.
This kind of relationship amounts to approximately what poly people call a "secondary partnership": emotionally intimate, but not the primary structure of one's life. This might work best for someone who already has a primary partner, or who is otherwise committing most of their energies to a high intensity project.
(
This somewhat-out-of-date document
gives some ideas for what that could look like, given my focus on my work.)
Long term - High intensity Partnership (with a capital P)
In the long run, I‚Äôm looking for a
spiritual collaborator
*, for the other half of an
altruistic power couple
.
I want a Partnership with someone relentlessly and ambitiously dedicated to improving the world, who is striving to grow in skill and wisdom, and who will mutally support me in doing the same. A relationship in which we work together, train together, rest together, and help each other to live in integrity with our values. This entails, among other things, spending a lot of time working.
(Some more operationalization of what this kind of relationship might look like
here
.)
* - To be clear, I am an atheist and an antitheist. It is an extremely important fact about the universe (and about my worldview) that we are
beyond the reach of God
. But I am deeply concerned with matters of the spirit, no matter that souls turn out to be implemented by neurons.
Constraints and relationship-essentials
Work
Out of a combination of personal inclination and moral commitment, I work a lot
. I spend the majority of my waking hours at the office working, training, studying. In between work blocks, I exercise, eat my one meal a day, and nap.
Anyone dating me in any recurring way will need to be ok with that, either because they have a similar orientation to the world themselves, or because they‚Äôre chill with a relationship that is intimate, without being time-intensive.
Honesty
The thing that is most important to me in all of my personal relationships is skilled honesty.
I've sometimes been in a context where there was a
forbidden conversation
, some true fact, or some belief I held, that I didn't feel free to acknowledge‚Äìbecause it would offend someone, or because it ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt my place‚Äù, or because pointing out some farce would make things worse, or because it seemed like it was intruding on the other person, who didn't want to hear it, etc. In a situation like this, I feel pressure to pretend about, or distract from, or downplay the thing.
I‚Äôve come to think that I can‚Äôt build a robust relationship on a foundation of this kind of holding back. I want to participate in contexts where I can be fully honest, and it is safe and practical for people to be fully honest with me, up to and including all of things that it is usually not polite or acceptable to say.
Creating those kinds of contexts by merely
intending to be honest
isn't sustainable. It requires skill to say the things that can't usually be said, in a way that doesn't do undue harm.
I make explicit considered effort in all my important relationships, to build an API such that the two of us can say anything (including our judgements, frustrations, and deep feedback) in a way that the other party can hear it without feeling attacked. And I‚Äôve sought to develop the skills to support this kind of honesty,
Nonviolent Communication
,
rationality
, and
circling
skill.
But even so, I am not a master at this. I still sometimes find myself in situations where there's something that feels too awkward to share even in otherwise candid relationships. I need help to maintain this kind of connection.
It is important to me that, between the two of us, we have enough skill to maintain this kind of connection: that it continues to feel possible, for you and for me, to share what‚Äôs up for us, even if that is uncomfortable or impolite or awkward. This is crucial for me in an intimate relationship.
Meta
Relatedly, relationships with me typically involve a lot of ‚Äúmeta‚Äù: doing checkins, talking about the relationship and how it is or isn't working, flagging frictions and generating creative solutions together, investing effort trying to improve our communication processes, etc.
Some past partners have found this onerous or annoying. ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt we skip all the process talk, and just do the cool things that the relationship is about?‚Äù I don‚Äôt see it that way. Much of what I care about in a relationship is the strength of the relationship itself, and this sort of meta and process-iteration is a means to that.
Completely unironically, leaving comments on my relationship-communication google docs is one of my love languages. (The google doc format is optional. That's just a communication method that has worked well for some past partners.)
Relationship style
I'm dispositionally monogamous, generally preferring to commit to only one person. However, I am happy to date people who have other partners themselves, especially if I can see that that makes them happy.
I have only ever seriously dated one person at a time, and incidentally, I have only ever seriously dated people who were poly. (Effectively, I was monogamously partnered with someone who was dating other people.)
I am more than willing to participate in a fully-monogamous partnership, if we're a good fit. I've dated poly people, not because I particularly prefer poly, but because the people I've been interested in have been poly.
Kids
Raising kids appeals to me, but I‚Äôm not currently planning around having a family in the pre-singularity. However, I would do that if I found a
highly
compatible partner and having kids was important to her.
That is to say, I am
open
to having kids, but only if we are an exceptionally good match.
I do have strong views about schooling and education.
I think that I am unusually committed to the good, which is probably somewhat heritable, and the world would be better if there were more people in it like me. If you wanted my sperm, without parental obligations, I am
likely
open to that, though I can probably suggest even better candidates.
(I think I will probably actively seek out a partner for raising a family after humanity is out of the
acute risk period
and life extension is solved.)
Sex
Sex is more important to me in the case of a once-or-twice-a-week companion than in the case of a committed Partnership. The point of having a capital-P partnership is mostly to help each other be better. For that, sex can be nice, but it isn't necessary. In the case of a more casual relationship, sexual and intimate emotional satisfaction is a larger fraction of what I care about.
I‚Äôm interested in doing deliberate practice to get good at sex: focusing on my partner‚Äôs experience, with ample verbal and nonverbal feedback (plus after-action debriefs). It would obviously be better to do this with an emotionally-intimate partner, but I'm potentially open to trying with someone who I'm not otherwise dating, if we can establish really good communication and clarity about expectations first.
Vegetarianism
I'm vegan (with
some caveats
). So far, 100% of the people that I've dated seriously and 100% of the people that I've ever been in love with have been vegan. This is mostly correlation‚Äîthe sort of people that I tend to be attracted to tend to be vegans. But it's
also
causal‚ÄîI care about the ethics of the people I spend time with. For most people, eating factory farmed meat is the habit that causes the most direct harm to others. (Additionally, seeing someone eat meat tends to reduce my level of attraction for them.)
I'm not confident, but I think I probably don't want to date people who aren't vegetarian, or who aren't otherwise careful about the externalities their life has on animals in factory farms.
I'm not listing this as a firm deal-breaker, but it is important to me. If you eat factory farmed meat, and we get moderately far into dating, I'll want to have an honest and reasoned conversation with you about the ethics and tradeoffs involved.
(I'm conscious that abstaining from animal products entirely is not a healthy choice for some people, and that there are additional tradeoffs.)
Some notes about the kind of person I'm looking for
I tend to like, and like spending time with, people who embody some combination of unusual moral commitment, high emotional/relational skill, and intellectual aliveness.
Some concrete, non-exhaustive, positive signs (both causal and statistical) that you might be the kind of person that I like...
You're vegan ¬∑ You've done more than 20 hours of circling ¬∑ You donate a largish-fraction 
  of your income, or did at some point in your life ¬∑ You majored in (or autodidacted) a STEM subject, or philosophy ¬∑ You don't drink alcohol ¬∑ You have a personal 
  practice of Gendlin Focusing or parts-work ¬∑ You were an EA before 2021 ¬∑ You've reflected seriously on ethics and integrity, and 
  have some provisional conclusions which guide your personal choices ¬∑ You prioritize exercise and 
  physical health ¬∑ You were raised in a Jewish household ¬∑ You write a blog about ideas ¬∑ You've read (most of) the LessWrong Sequences ¬∑ You 
  invest heavily in personal development ¬∑ You identify as libertarian ¬∑ You identify as anarchist ¬∑ You enjoy or have been involved with musical theater ¬∑ You 
  distinguish between the social justice issues that are rolling moral catastrophes and the ones that 
  don't matter ¬∑ You have at least one private or public writeup of how you think about ethics or a particular 
  ethical decision ¬∑ You journal regularly ¬∑ You consider "having true beliefs" to be an ethical imperative
You absolutely don't have to match all of that (or even most of it!). If you value similar things, consider reaching out. : )
Some friends' descriptions of me:
Friend 1:
"Erudite, stoic, and unrelentingly devoted to good. Also a little bit clumsy, but you can leave that part out.‚Äù
Friend 2:
"Human, on the lower end of height but upper percentage of brain capacity with a weird interest in saying true things, keeping commitments, and deliberately practicing skills he wants to get good at."
Friend 3:
‚ÄúEli is kind of what you would imagine a human might be like if you hadn't met any humans but had built a lot of houses.‚Äù
If you want to say hello...
If any of the above sounds interesting to you, or even if you just want to say hi, 
press
this button
to tell me your name and a few sentences about you (or just email me
here
). Maybe we can meet up the next time
		we're in the same metropolitan area.
I'm grateful to everyone who takes initiative and reaches out, even if it turns out we're not a good match. In
an important way
, your 
	doing that is the only reason this system works at all. So thank you.
If you would like more detail about who I am, or what I care about, you might explore the rest of this site, particularly the
public statements page
, or flip through my
blog
and/or
archived twitter threads
.
Aid my quest!
If you‚Äôre not a good match with me (you‚Äôre male, or married, or want something different than I do), but you'd like this project to succeed, 
	you can help by connecting me with thoughtful, single (or non-polysaturated) women who want the sort of thing that I want.
If you took even 5 minutes right now to flip through your facebook friends and consider if any of them might want to date someone like me, you will earn my
gratitude
.
